column4: I tried cat /dev/psaux and then moving the mouse, but that did help.
oh, that means if nothing is screwed up with cat, then the mouse is not detected/connected?
hm, in that case I suspect that some drivers are not loaded. I need to enable my laptop touchpad.
my USB mouse was plugged in at that time and it works. There is just no provision for both mice in XF86Config-4.
I have XF86Config-4 open in an editor on tty1 (the batteries of my USB mouse are empty and X is no fun without a mouse).
And I have already frobbed it. To no avail so far.
Before I proceed I want to make sure that it is actually detected by the kernel.
Since cat /dev/psaux does not produce garbage characters and screw my screen, I suspect that it is not.
What do I need to do to make Ubuntu reckognize my touchpad?
Fujitu/Siemens Amilo.  It used to be unproblematic back then with Debian Woody, though.
mice: PS/2 mouse device common for all mice
I tried cat as root, but I'll try xxd now to make sure.
the USB receiver is listed in /proc/bus/input/devices; the USB mouse is out of battery right now. :)
go to bios and disable something like the parallel port and see if that frees it up
o.k. I'll be back in a minute or two.
